hit.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to touch someone or something quickly and hard with your hand, a stick etc
hit.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: He raised the hammer and hit the bell.
The robbers hit him over the head with a baseball bat.
hit.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to move into something or someone quickly and with force
hit.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: The tanks exploded as the plane hit the ground.
He was hit by a car.
hit.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to move a part of your body quickly against something accidentally, causing pain
hit.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: The ceiling’s low, so be careful you don’t hit your head.
She slipped and hit her head on the sidewalk.
hit.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: if you hit a ball or other object, you make it move forward quickly by hitting it with a bat, stick etc
hit.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: Hit the ball as hard as you can.
hit.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to get points by hitting a ball in a game such as baseball or cricket
hit.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: Last year, Griffey hit 49 home runs.
hit.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: to press a part in a machine, car, etc to make it work
hit.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: Maria hit the brakes just in time.
hit.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: to attack something or wound someone with a bomb, bullet etc
hit.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: Our ship was badly hit and sank within minutes.
A second shot hit her in the back.
The bomb failed to hit its target.
hit.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: if something bad hits a place or a person, it suddenly happens and affects people badly
hit.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: The village has been hit by a devastating drought.
Hurricane Louis is expected to hit at the weekend.
The south of the country is the worst hit by the recession.
The company has been hard hit by the drop in consumer confidence.
hit.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: My father hit a bad patch, and had to sell the house.
hit a snag/problems/a bad patch etc
hit.translation[0].definitions[9].defini: to reach a particular level or number
hit.translation[0].definitions[9].exampl: Sales have hit the 1 million mark.
Earnings hit a peak in the early 1980s.
hit a peak/an all-time high etc
hit.translation[0].definitions[10].defin: if a fact hits you, you suddenly realize its importance and feel surprised or shocked
hit.translation[0].definitions[10].examp: It’s impossible to pinpoint a moment when it hit me that I was ‘a success’.
He was gone before they knew what had hit them  (=realized what had happened).
hit.translation[0].definitions[11].defin: if a smell or sight hits you, you suddenly smell or see it
hit.translation[0].definitions[11].examp: The smell of stale smoke hit him as he entered.
hit.translation[0].definitions[12].examp: They hit the main road two kilometres further on.
I’ll look for work as soon as I hit town.
hit.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: to hit someone
to hit someone quickly and hard with your hand, a stick etc
He hit him hard in the stomach.
I don’t like to see people hitting a dog.
beat
to hit someone deliberately many times, especially very hard
The girl had been beaten to death.
He was beating the donkey with a stick.
strike
to hit someone with your hand or a weapon. Strike  is more formal than hit and is mainly used in written English
Her husband struck her twice across the face.
Police say that the man had been struck on the head.
punch
to hit someone hard with your closed hand, especially in a fight
I punched him on the nose.
She was screaming and punching him with her fists.
thump
to punch someone very hard
Sometimes I just want to thump him.
beat somebody up
to hurt someone badly in a violent attack, by hitting them many times
If I tell the police, they'll beat me up.
He had been beaten up and tortured with lighted cigarettes.
slap
to hit someone with your open hand, especially because you are angry with them
They had a big row and she ended up slapping him.
spank
to hit someone, especially a child, with your open hand in order to punish them
Should a parent ever smack a child?
I don’t agree with smacking.
In those days, children were spanked if they behaved badly.
to hit something
Jack hit the ball and it flew over the fence.
knock
to hit a door or window with your closed hand in order to attract the attention of the people inside
Someone was knocking on the door.
I knocked loudly but no one came.
strike
to hit a surface. Strike is more formal than hit and is mainly used in written English
The ball struck the side of the goal.
whack
to hit something very hard
Edmonds whacked the ball into the air.
bash
to hit something hard, especially in a way that causes damage
The police had to bash the door down to get in.
tap
to gently hit something with your fingers, often in order to attract someone’s attention
I tapped him on the shoulder.
I heard someone tapping on the window.
rap
to knock quickly or hit something several times
He rapped the table with his pen to bring the meeting to order.
Two police officers rapped on the door at 7 o'clock in the morning.
bang
to suddenly hit something hard, in a way that makes a loud noise
Her father banged his fist down on the table angrily.
The door suddenly banged shut.
pound
to hit something many times with a lot of force
I could hear the sea pounding on the rocks.
She pounded on the door and shouted wildly.
hammer
to hit something quickly many times making a loud continuous noise
The rain was hammering on the roof.
A crowd of people were outside hammering on the door angrily.
to hit something accidentally
I’ve got a bad bruise where I hit my leg against the table.
The car hit a tree.
bump
to hit a part of your body against something, especially because you do not see or notice it
Careful you don’t bump your head – the ceiling’s very low.
bang/bash
to hit something hard, so that you hurt yourself or damage something
He banged into the car in front.
I bashed my knee climbing over a gate.
She fell and bashed her chin on the ground.
stub
to hit your toe against something and hurt it
I stubbed my toe on the piano leg.
hit.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: something such as a film, play, song etc that is very popular and successful
hit.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: the hit musical ‘The Phantom of the Opera’
Which band had a hit with ‘Bohemian Rhapsody’?
It’s hoped the new museum will be a big hit with families.
hit.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: an occasion when something that is aimed at something else touches it, reaches it, or damages it
hit.translation[1].definitions[1].exampl: Our ship took a direct hit and sank.
hit.translation[1].definitions[2].defini: an occasion when someone visits a website
hit.translation[1].definitions[2].exampl: The site had 2,000 hits in the first week.
hit.translation[1].definitions[3].defini: a result of a computer search, especially on the Internet
hit.translation[1].definitions[4].defini: a feeling of pleasure obtained from taking an illegal drug
hit.translation[1].definitions[5].defini: a murder that has been arranged to happen
hit.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: to reach a particular level or number
hit.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: Profits should hit $23 million this year.
The company’s shares hit a 52-week high of $34 last Friday.
hit.translation[2].definitions[1].defini: to have a bad effect on something
hit.translation[2].definitions[1].exampl: Strikes hit several ports in Australia last month.
The industry has beenbadly hit by the rise in oil prices.
A number of computer retail chains have beenhit hard by the recession.
hit.translation[2].definitions[2].defini: when a RECESSION hits, it begins
hit.translation[2].definitions[2].exampl: A final blow to the company came when the recession hit in 1990.
hit.translation[2].definitions[3].defini: to become available for people to buy
hit.translation[2].definitions[3].exampl: This new generation of computers is expected to hit the market some time next year.
hit.translation[2].definitions[4].defini: to be very successful and make a lot of money
hit.translation[2].definitions[4].exampl: The company hit the jackpot with its New Kids range of clothing.
hit.translation[3].definitions[0].defini: something that is extremely popular and successful
hit.translation[3].definitions[0].exampl: Their latest computer game has been abig hit with customers.
The group is currently on tour promoting its latesthit single.
hit.translation[3].definitions[1].defini: if a person or organization takes a hit, they suffer from a problem
hit.translation[3].definitions[1].exampl: The construction industry took a serious hit as jobs declined by 37,000 during the first 10 months of the year.
hit.translation[3].definitions[2].defini: if a company takes a hit in its financial results, it pays a CHARGE (=a cost related to a particular event, usually one that is not repeated in later periods of time)
hit.translation[3].definitions[2].exampl: The bank took a huge hit in charges to clean up the mess in its African subsidiaries.
hit.translation[3].definitions[3].defini: an occasion when someone looks at a particular WEBSITE on the Internet
hit.translation[3].definitions[3].exampl: The Winter Olympics website had over 600 million hits in 16 days.
